Posts.Title: November Rads 2009 amlg1 EngTchr

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2010 02:23PM cheers247 wrote: Hello Feroza, certain chemothrapy drugs are vesicants, and cannot be infused into a periferal vein, and need to be infused into a central line or port.  The port does not have to be drained... and you can take a shower just like you normally would.  I have had my port since last April.  Other than having a scar where it was incerted, you can't tell it's there.  You can see pictures if you google port-a-cath.  Talk to your MD about what type of chemo you will have, and if it can be infused into an arm vein.  Much love!  Jessica

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2009 01:57PM cheers247 wrote: Hi Faith 316, My understanding is that IBC patient's have to wait at least a year for recon.  Skin mets are a risk, and in surgery they usually take lots of skin and tissue.  There is also a high recurrence rate with IBC.  I just had a bilat mast, and my BS told me I am a long way from even thinking about recon.  When/if I do, it will be a DIEP I think.  Check the IBC boards too.  Much Love, Jessica

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2009 02:16PM cheers247 wrote: Thanks Dawn!  I reacted to the Taxotere, they tried to run it slower and with a wopping dose of Solu-Medrol, but I reacted again, so they think I have a true allergy to it.  I'm doing better on the AC there is a lot of nausea though, my second AC is on Tues. I will have 4 total AC's.   They give lots of benedryl with the taxanes, so expect to be sleepy, and they do take longer than AC.  Keep me posted on how you do!  Jessica
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo April 2009 tulipbebe MissouriCatLady

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2009 04:29PM cheers247 wrote: Hello, I just found this thread, I started TCH on 4/28, and had to switch to AC after my second treatment becasue of an adverse reaction to T.  I've had one round of AC, and will start the H again after I'm done with the AC.  Then I will have a double mast & total hyst.  No fertility treatments for me, I'm 34, but have been postmeno since I was 29.  No Dr. has been able to tell me why my ovaries failed, but they sure did.  I took HRT for 4 years, now I have cancer... imagine that.  After my surgery I'm going to have 6wks of daily rad, and a year of H.  It's so nice to be able to talk to people who are at the same stage in the process as I am. Much Love, Jessica
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo April 2009 tulipbebe MissouriCatLady

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2009 07:04PM cheers247 wrote: I'm so sorry you are going through this!!  Request that your GYN order you a mamo and ultrasound, they may be negative, but also ask for a biopsy of the reddened skin and an MRI, which are more accurate at diagnosing/ruling out IBC. A breast surgeon is usually the one to make the IBC diagnosis if there is one.  PLease keep us posted!  Much Love to you!!!  Jessica
Posts.Title: red rash on right breast rovaries rovaries

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2009 06:01PM cheers247 wrote: rovaries:  My punch biopsy was negative, but my skin was thickened, and my internal biopsy showed cancer.  You would still need a mamo and MRI to get accurately diagnosed.  I'm glad you got a biopsy today!  Keep us posted and take care! xoxo Jessica PS, feel free to send me a private message if you want to

Posts.Title: Starting Chemo April 2009 tulipbebe MissouriCatLady

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2009 10:22AM cheers247 wrote: Hello ladies... I'm so glad many of you feel the way I do, I feel like I don't know my body anymore.  Talk about sexless... I'm going to have a bilat mastectomy and a total hysterectomy in the fall after chemo's done.  Will I even be a girl anymore? I'm 34, and divorced... outlook does not look good for dating in the future! Titan:  I had terrible bone pain with Neulasta, then with my last treatment I took Clairitin (OTC allergy med) 1 tab the day before chemo, chemo day and the the day after chemo, and had NO PAIN!!  Clairitin is a H2 receptor blocker, and it amazingly worked, no pain and blood counts were good!  I will surely be taking it again, next chemo is tomorrow!  Much Love to all!  Jessica
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo April 2009 tulipbebe MissouriCatLady

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2009 10:57AM cheers247 wrote: Hello Dawn, Taxotere is the one with the additives that can cause the reactions, and is the one I reacted to at first. My onc. wants me to try Taxol with Herceptin after the ACx4, my immune system will be so beat up that I won't be able to react to it, is the though process, we'll see.  I am allergic to Decadron (I guess I'm a "delicate flower", as my onc. calls me.)  I can take other steroids though if needed.  Emend does work for me, and I was not nausated at all when I took the TCH x2, but the AC really makes me queezy, so I take Aloxi and Zofran too.  I hope you have a great weekend!!! Loves, Jessica
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo April 2009 tulipbebe MissouriCatLady

Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 04:53PM cheers247 wrote: I had all of those tests done too, they were done the week I was diagnosed, along with getting my port placed.  I'll have 6mos of chemo & herceptin, then a double mast & total hyst in the fall, then 6wks of daily rads & another year of herceptin.  The treatment for IBS is different than for other bc's, but there is standard testing for all breast cancer's and your doctor is covering all the bases by ordering all the standard tests.  It may seem excessive at this time, but the results will be used now and in the future to evaluate your response to therapy etc.  Much love, Jessica

Much Love!  Jessica

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2009 07:11PM cheers247 wrote: Hello ladies, I just came across this thread, and I am so glad I did.  My kitty Cheers is 8 years old.  She was diagnosed with BC a year before me.  I elected not to do chemo for her, she gets so distressed when she has to leave the house.  I keep her at home, and make her life as comfy as possible.  She eats lots of tuna, and loves the juice.  She still plays every day.  I can tell when she's not feeling well, she won't get up on those days.  Most days thought, I wouldn't know she had cancer if I couldn't feel the masses.  I'll be thinking of all of your furbabies too!  Jessica
Posts.Title: So Sad... not about cancer LittleFlower LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2010 12:00AM cheers247 wrote: Hi ladies, it's been quite a while since I've posted.  After more than a year on medical leave my Onc finally released me to return to work but he wrote so many restrictions that HR says I cannot go back to my old position (post partum RN) so they are looking for another "temporary" position for me somewhere else in the hospital.  I'm really feeling robbed by this disease, I'm worried I'll never be able to do what I love again.  I'm so glad there is a place for nurses here!  Much love to you all! Jessica www.caringbridge.org/visit/jessicam

Posts.Title: Refuse To Do Surgery makingway nelia48

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2010 11:31PM cheers247 wrote: I had my power port put in last April.  It was really sore, and I couldn't wear a bra either (I had chemo before the BMX), it just rubbed too much.  I alAso noticed that the port slowly got closer to the surface of the skin, which feels weird, but makes it easier to access.  Since the BMX, it is painful all over again, and it hurts more when it is accessed.  When I have my labs drawn and my Herceptin or Zometa, I use the Lido cream, and have some Lido injected to help, it still hurts some though.  I'd much rather have this port than use and fry my arm veins though.

Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2010 11:47PM cheers247 wrote: Hi In-Cognito, my Onc wrote some lifting restrictions I have LE in my right arm.  He also wrote that I'm not to carry things and walk at the same time... espeically babies (I'm a L&D & post partum RN)  So it's a problem.  My feet are completely numb from Taxanes.  My last chemo was in Sept. and there is no sign of it getting any better yet.  I have near falls daily.  I also have pretty significant "chemo brain" so he wrote that I cannot pass meds, he wrote that we would "re-evaluate" all of this in 6-12mos.  I sure hope this gets better so I can get back to work. Jessica www.caringbridge.org/visit/jessicam
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2010 01:20AM cheers247 wrote: Hi Diane, I do wear a sleeve and glove for LE compression.  I am not back to work yet, and I have wondered how I will manage the hand washing issue.  It's such a pain to take that thing on and off.  We use Purel gel a lot on our nursing units, and it will be a pain for sure!  It's just one more thing we have to do as survivors I guess.  Let me know if you come up with a system that makes it easier for you.  Much Love, Jessica www.caringbridge.org/visit/jessicam
